summary: Joachim F. Pehl, also known as Joachim S. Beer, is the step-son of Henry S. Beer. Agent reports from March 1971 detail derogatory information found on Joachim, including reports of a fire and disturbing the peace while he served in the US Army Berlin Brigade. Local agency checks revealed similar derogatory information from the Provost Marshal's Office (PMO) regarding these incidents. A cable from BLN STA 66th MI GP, also from March 1971, indicates that LAC's and MAC's checks on Joachim were mostly negative or non-derogatory, except for the disturbing the peace incident. The cable also details Joachim Raf. Beer's background as a former labor service employee and his immigration processing.
significance: The significance of Joachim F. Pehl in the JFK assassination context is not explicitly stated in the provided documents. The documents primarily focus on derogatory information and background checks related to him, possibly as part of an investigation or security assessment related to his step-father, Henry S. Beer. The documents do not directly link him to the assassination.
